fields.description: We currently hard code our heap size if it is not explicitly set by the admin. We should be using our bootstrap logic to come up with a reasonable default based on the state/capacity of the system we are running. If the user sets their own value we should still honor it.
fields.summary: Java bootstrapper should set a reasonable heap size by default when starting up

comments.body: The current plan is to set Xms and Xmx to half of total memory on the box unless user set Xms. If user set Xms to a small value (less than 2G) system will alert about small heap size. [~sjones],[~zhill], [~viglesias], any objections to that approach?

Setting an overly large heap can cause performance issues when GC finally kicks in and tries to process a large amount of garbage. I would limit the maximum size we use automatically (16GiB?) and would not enforce a lower limit to the user configured value.

I'd remove the floor or replace it with at most a warning.  2G might be an appropriate minimum for a system that runs every single java-based service, but it ignores people who only run a subset of services or people who otherwise know what they're doing.  I routinely run UFS groups on VMs with much less memory than my CLCs, for instance.  If enforcing a certain minimum despite the explicit decision of the cloud admin is desirable for some reason we should handle that in a separate bug.
The size calculation should also have a lower limit of 2G just to be safe. I think 50% is a reasonable number.
Not disagreeing with others' suggestions, they just arrived after I opened the comment box. Both good points.

System would automatically set Java heap size to a half of memory (1G min and 16G max). System would set value only if user have not specify any value for max heap size. If user set max heap size to a value that is less than 1G a warning is logged in the startup log. [~sjones] or [~zhill], could you look at my change (Commit c4beceb70ced1bd25340a36798d69add5f32d10b in the dev-vasya-EUCA-10794 branch)?

[~vasya], looks good to me generally. I would keep the existing 2g lower limit for automatic settings, the minimum system requirement is 4g. It would be better if we rounded down to the nearest gigabyte rather than configuring a value in bytes.
[~sjones], what is the benefit of using GBs in Xmx vs bytes?
[~vasya], GBs are easier to understand than a large number of bytes.

[~sjones], I think using GB is not a good idea. Our QA hosts reports 7.6G or RAM. Half of that is 3.8 but rounding this down is 3. If we round it down to nearest GBs we would allocate 20% less memory. I think we can round it to MB is we really want to make it more human readable.
I would say 3g is a reasonable default, 3891m less so.

I'd like to have a third opinion on that. [~viglesias], [~gholms], [~zhill] any preferences on heap size denominator? I'd also like to point out that the only way that I know to see the actual value is to run system with debug flag and look into startup.log, therefore I don't get why it has to be human friendly.

I'd like to keep it to round GB numbers for both readability and logical debugging. Checking if a process is using 4G of memory is easier than 3.8G, and is more intuitive. The intent here is to make reasonable, not perfect, values. Given that most systems will have an even amount of memory (7.6 is actual 8GB in QA) we can ceiling that number and div by 2 and truncated any remainder. The readability is important in the logs and for machine parsing later, so it's not a hidden value--particularly since we're auto-setting it now and users will want to know what value was used.

[~mbacchi], User are expected to modify eucalyptus.conf file and should not exit eucalyptus-cloud script. You can add any JVM options to the CLOUD_OPTS property. They will be passed to the JVM. If user adds --debug in the CLOUD_OPTS all user defined and default JVM parameter will be spitted to the log. I don't think we need to do any extra work, but feel free to open a separate improvement bug if you think something should be changed.
